content.html:
Activity

\(H(t)\) is the percentage of homes in the United States that have a landline phone in year \(t\). \(C(t)\) is the percentage of homes with only a cell phone. Here are the graphs of \(H\) and \(C\).



  1. Estimate \(H(2006)\) and \(C(2006)\). Explain what each value tells us about the phones.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(H(2006)\) is about 85, and \(C(2006)\) is about 14. In 2006, 85% of homes had a landline phone, and 14% of homes had only a cell phone.



  1. What is the approximate solution to \(C(t)=20\)? Explain what the solution means in this situation.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Approximately 2008. It means that around 2008, 20% of homes used only cell phones.



  1. Determine if each equation is true. Be prepared to explain how you know.

    1. \(C(2011)=H(2011)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, because \(C(2011)\) is about 30 and \(H(2011)\) is about 70. The percentage of homes with a landline phone and the percentage of homes with only a cell phone were not equal.



    1. \(C(2015)=H(2015)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes, because in 2015 the percentage of homes with a landline and the percentage of homes with only a cell phone were equal, as shown by the intersection of the graphs.



  1.    
    1. Between 2004 and 2015, did the percentage of homes with landlines decrease at the same rate at which the percentage of cell-phones-only homes increased?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, the percentage of cell-phones-only homes increased at a rate close to that by which the percentage of landline-owning homes decreased, but not exactly the same.



    1. Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  • In 2004, only about 6% of homes had only cell phones. In 2015, about 48% did. The average rate of change for \(C\) is \(\frac{48-6}{2015-2004}=\frac{42}{11}\), or about 3.8. This means the percentage of homes relying only on cell phones grew by about 3.8% each year.
  • In 2004, about 92% of homes had a landline. In 2015, only about 48% did. The average rate of change for \(H\) is \(\frac{48-92}{2015-2004}=\frac{-44}{11}\), or –4. This means the percentage of homes that used landlines fell by 4% each year.


Extending Your Thinking

  1. Explain why the statement \(C(t)+H(t)\leq100\) is true in this situation. Enter your answer here:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Each household either has a landline or has no landline and relies only on cell phones, so \(H(t)\) and \(C(t)\) calculate separate groups of people. As long as there are not rounding errors, \(H(t)\) and \(C(t)\) together can only be 100 percent, and it will be less if there are people with no phone service at all.


  1. What value does \(C(t)+H(t)\) appear to take between 2004 and 2017? How much does this value vary in that interval?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It appears to take a value a little less than 100, maybe close to 97. For example, the two graphs meet below the midway point (50). At the beginning and the end of the shown interval, they add up to a little less than 100 as well. The sum is not constant (the shapes of the two graphs are different) but does not vary much, so the percentage of people with no phone service is small for the entire period.
